title: 115_s982
content: The Act may be cited as the "Speak Up to Protect Every Abused Kid Act". Congress expresses its sense. Congress emphasizes the importance of adults in children's lives for their safety and well-being. Data shows a high number of child abuse cases in the US, with many resulting in death. Every adult has a moral obligation to report any suspicions of child abuse, regardless of legal requirements. Federal standards should be set for mandated reporters. State law mandates certain individuals as reporters to protect children and ensure consistency among state laws, with the flexibility for states to add more mandated reporters. SEC. 3. EDUCATIONAL CAMPAIGNS AND TRAINING. The Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act is amended to include a new section on educational campaigns and training. The Secretary will provide grants for educational campaigns and training on mandatory reporting of child abuse. Guidance will be given on best practices for educating the public on recognizing abuse, reporting responsibilities, and available resources for families. Entities eligible for grants must submit an application to the Secretary for an educational campaign or training program focused on preventing child abuse and neglect. Funds received must be used for the specified purposes outlined in the guidance provided by the Secretary. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2017 and $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2018 through 2021 to carry out educational campaigns or training programs for preventing child abuse and neglect. Grants to states for child abuse or neglect prevention and treatment programs. Section 106(b) of the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act is amended to require a certification by the Governor of the State that the State has laws or programs in place for reporting child abuse and neglect to a State child protective service. The amendment to the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act requires the Governor to certify that the State has laws for reporting child abuse and neglect to a State child protective service or law enforcement agency. Additionally, it mandates mandatory reporting and coordination procedures in the State plan. The State must ensure coordination between the State law or program, law enforcement, and victims' services agencies to refer child victims of non-parental abuse for follow-up services, even if they do not qualify for protections under the State law. The State must investigate reports of child abuse or neglect, even if the incident occurred in a different State. They should share investigation results with the States where the child and alleged perpetrator reside. If the incident did not occur in the State where the child or alleged perpetrator resides, they should establish a process for handling the case. The State must establish a plan to assist with investigating child abuse, including screening for domestic violence in consultation with relevant entities and providing training. The State must establish a plan to assist with investigating child abuse, including screening for domestic violence and providing training requirements for investigators. Individuals in health-related fields licensed by the State must report suspected or known incidents of child abuse or neglect. The individuals mandated to report child abuse include those in various professions such as mental health providers, school employees, law enforcement personnel, clergy, daycare workers, social services employees, foster parents, and court-appointed special advocates. The reporting requirement for individuals mandated to report child abuse includes court-appointed special advocates, camp and after-school employees, individuals integral to programs, and others as required by state law. They must report suspected or known incidents directly to law enforcement or child welfare agencies. Employees mandated to report child abuse must report incidents directly to law enforcement or child welfare agencies, and possibly to their supervisor or employer as required by State law. SEC. 5. APPROACHES AND TECHNIQUES TO IMPROVE REPORTING. (a) Eligibility for training adults working with children to report child abuse or neglect under State law is amended. (b) State Task Force Study under the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act is also amended. The amendment includes evaluating the State's efforts to train adults working with children to report child abuse or neglect under State law. Additionally, it introduces experimental programs to improve reporting and response to child abuse incidents. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of reporting child abuse or neglect to the State child protective service agencies or law enforcement agencies. SEC. 6. GENERAL PROGRAM GRANTS. Amends the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act to require states to have mandatory reporting laws to receive financial assistance. SEC. 7. REPORTS. Section 110 of the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act is amended to include a study and report on State mandatory reporting laws regarding child abuse or neglect. The Secretary will collect information and assess the implementation of these laws, submitting a report to Congress within 4 years. The study under paragraph (1) will provide an update on the implementation of State laws for mandatory reporting and State efforts to improve reporting on child abuse or neglect. It will also include data on changes in substantiated child abuse reports and child abuse fatalities since the enactment of the Speak Up to Protect Every Abused Kid Act. SEC. 8. COMMUNITY-BASED GRANTS. Amends the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act to include an assurance that states have mandatory reporting laws. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act takes effect upon enactment, with mandatory reporting requirements applying to plans submitted after 2 years.
